questions.text: A 30-year-old woman comes to the primary care physician because she has felt nauseous and fatigued for 3 weeks. Menses occur at irregular 24- to 33-day intervals and last for 4–6 days. Her last menstrual period was 7 weeks ago. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 95/min, and blood pressure is 100/70 mm Hg. Pelvic examination shows an enlarged uterus. Her serum β-hCG concentration is 96,000 mIU/mL (N < 5). An abdominal ultrasound is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although a bicornuate uterus pregnancy could manifest as two separate cavities on ultrasound, a single embryo usually appears in only one horn of the malformed uterus while the other horn is empty. In contrast, this patient presents with two, clearly visible embryos on ultrasonography. Also, a bicornuate uterus is associated with other features, such as a past history of dyspareunia, menorrhagia, etc., which this patient lacks.

B) INCORRECT:

This patient presents with an elevated serum beta-hCG and 7 weeks of amenorrhea, indicating a live pregnancy. Her ultrasonography clearly shows two embryos, which indicates a twin pregnancy. However, a monochorionic-diamniotic twin pregnancy is characterized on ultrasonography by the "T" sign; a thin membrane resembling the letter "T" separates the amniotic sacs within a common chorionic sac. This typical feature is absent in this patient's ultrasonography.
Image Description:

Ultrasound pelvis (gravid uterus)

Adjacent twins are separated by a thin membrane, which terminates at the placenta in a T configuration (T sign). This T sign is an indicator of a monochorionic diamniotic twin pregnancy.

A monochorionic diamniotic gestation may alternatively create a black triangular space (known as black lambda sign) at the uterine wall. This should not be confused with the triangular projection of chorion, which creates the lambda sign of a dichorionic pregnancy.

C) INCORRECT:

The ultrasonography in this patient clearly depicts two embryos enclosed within the uterine cavity. Moreover, an ectopic pregnancy (i.e., abdominal/interstitial pregnancy) presents with abdominal pain and cervical motion tenderness, which are absent in this patient.

D) CORRECT:

This patient presents elevated serum beta-hCG and 7 weeks of amenorrhea, indicating a live pregnancy. Her ultrasonography clearly shows two embryos, each with an individual gestational and amniotic sac. Also, a typical lambda sign is seen where the chorion joins the placenta. These findings are characteristic of a dichorionic-diamniotic twin pregnancy.
Image Description:

Ultrasound pelvis (gravid uterus)

A thick inter-twin membrane containing both amnion and chorion separates adjacent twin embryos, with a triangular projection of chorion visible at the base of the membrane. The appearance produced by this projection of tissue has been termed the lambda sign (also the twin peak sign) because of its resemblance to the Greek symbol λ (blue overlay).

Although its absence is not sufficient to exclude dichorionicity, the lambda sign is a strong indicator of a dichorionic diamniotic pregnancy. In a monochorionic diamniotic pregancy, the inter-twin membrane may either terminate in a T configuration (T sign) or create a black triangular space with the uterine wall, sometimes termed the black lambda sign.

E: embryo; yellow overlay: uterine wall

E) INCORRECT:

Prolonged amenorrhea, elevated β-hCG levels, and the appearance of embryonal parts on ultrasonography may indicate a partial hydatidiform mole. However, a partial hydatidiform mole is also associated with an enlarged placenta and cystic spaces within the placenta, both of which are absent here.
Image Description:

GTD is a group of diseases that originate in the placenta and typically result from abnormal fertilization of the ovum. Complete and partial moles may develop malignant traits and become invasive. Choriocarcinoma may be preceded by hydatidiform moles (50% of cases), ectopic pregnancy or miscarriages, or normal pregnancy.

Theca lutein cysts result from exaggerated stimulation of the theca interna cells of the ovarian follicles due to excessive amounts of beta-hCG.

F) INCORRECT:

A hydatidiform mole may be suspected in a case of prolonged amenorrhea associated with elevated beta-hCG levels. However, ultrasonography in a molar pregnancy would not reveal any fetal parts or amniotic fluid, but rather an echogenic mass interspersed with many hypoechogenic cystic spaces (“Swiss cheese,” “bunch of grapes,” or “snowstorm” appearance). Moreover, the elevation in serum beta-hCG levels is usually markedly higher (> 100,000 mIU/mL) than expected for the gestational age in molar pregnancies.
Image Description:

Ultrasound pelvis (transvaginal) of pregnant patient with abnormally elevated β-hCG level

There is no intrauterine gestation. An intrauterine mass (green outline) contains multiple cystic spaces (examples indicated by red overlay), which correspond to hydropic trophoblastic villi.

This vesicular appearance seen in a molar pregnancy has been described as a “snowstorm pattern”.

questions.text: A 2250-g (5.0-lb) male newborn and a 2900-g (6.4-lb) male newborn are delivered at 36 weeks' gestation to a 24-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1. The mother had no prenatal care. Examination of the smaller newborn shows low-set ears, retrognathia, and right-sided clubfoot. The hematocrit is 41% for the smaller newborn and 69% for the larger newborn. This pregnancy was most likely which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

All dizygotic twin pregnancies are dichorionic-diamniotic. Since each fetus has its own placenta and circulation, it is not possible for vascular anastomoses to develop that could lead to twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome.

B) INCORRECT:

Approximately 20–30% of monozygotic twin pregnancies are dichorionic-diamniotic. Since each fetus has its own placenta and circulation, it is not possible for vascular anastomoses to develop that could lead to twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome.

C) CORRECT:

Approximately 70% of monozygotic twin pregnancies are monochorionic-diamniotic. Sharing a common placenta can lead to twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome, a complication caused by unbalanced vascular anastomoses in which blood flows in a fixed direction from one twin to the other. Since the fetuses have separate amniotic sacs, this causes oligohydramnios in the donor twin's amniotic sac and polyhydramnios in the recipient twin's amniotic sac. The donor twin develops anemia, oliguria, and complications of oligohydramnios (e.g., craniofacial abnormalities and clubfoot due to intrauterine growth restriction). The recipient twin develops polycythemia.

D) INCORRECT:

Conjoined twins are a rare type of monochorionic-monoamniotic pregnancy that occurs when cleavage of the embryo occurs > 13 days after fertilization. Although vascular anastomoses between conjoined twins can lead to shunting of blood from one twin to the other, it is unlikely to cause a difference in hematocrit because of shared blood supply. Moreover, conjoined twin pregnancies are associated with polyhydramnios, not oligohydramnios.

E) INCORRECT:

Dichorionic-monoamniotic monozygotic twin pregnancies are not possible. The amnion develops within the chorion. If the chorion has cleaved (dichorionic), then each will form its own amnion (diamniotic). It is not possible to have one amnion within two chorions.

F) INCORRECT:

Monozygotic twin pregnancies are rarely monochorionic-monoamniotic. Twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome can develop in these pregnancies because of the shared placenta and cause a discrepancy in hematocrit. However, because the fetuses share one amniotic sac, complications of oligohydramnios affecting only one of the twins would not be expected. Monochorionic-monoamniotic twin pregnancies can be complicated by umbilical cord entanglement rather than amniotic fluid discordance.
questions.hint: Delivery of twins with a significant disparity in birth weight and hematocrit, along with complications of oligohydramnios (e.g., clubfoot, low-set ears, retrognathia) in the smaller newborn, should raise concern for twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome.

questions.text: A 2050-g (4.5-lb) female newborn and a 2850-g (6.3-lb) female newborn are delivered at 37 weeks' gestation to a 23-year-old, gravida 2, para 1 woman. The mother had no prenatal care. Examination of the smaller newborn shows a flattened nose and left-sided clubfoot. The hematocrit is 42% for the smaller newborn and 71% for the larger newborn. This pregnancy was most likely which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Approximately 70% of monozygotic twin pregnancies are monochorionic-diamniotic. Sharing a common placenta can lead to twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome, a complication caused by unbalanced vascular anastomoses in which blood flows in a fixed direction from one twin to the other. Since the fetuses have separate amniotic sacs, this causes oligohydramnios (in the donor twin's amniotic sac) and polyhydramnios (in the recipient twin's amniotic sac). The donor twin develops anemia, oliguria, and complications of oligohydramnios (e.g., craniofacial abnormalities and clubfoot due to intrauterine growth restriction). The recipient twin develops polycythemia.

In monozygotic twinning events, chorionicity and amnionicity depend on the timing of cleavage. The pregnancy will be dichorionic-diamniotic if cleavage occurs 0–3 days after fertilization, monochorionic-diamniotic if cleavage occurs 4–7 days after fertilization, and monochorionic-monoamniotic if cleavage occurs 8–12 days after fertilization.

B) INCORRECT:

All dizygotic twin pregnancies are dichorionic-diamniotic. Since each fetus has its own placenta and circulation, it is not possible for vascular anastomoses to develop that could lead to twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome.

C) INCORRECT:

Approximately 20–30% of monozygotic twin pregnancies are dichorionic-diamniotic. Since each fetus has its own placenta and circulation, it is not possible for vascular anastomoses to develop that could lead to twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome.

D) INCORRECT:

Dichorionic-monoamniotic monozygotic twin pregnancies are not possible. The amnion develops within the chorion. If the chorion has cleaved (dichorionic), then each will form its own amnion (diamniotic). It is not possible to have one amnion within two chorions.

E) INCORRECT:

Conjoined twins are a rare type of monochorionic-monoamniotic pregnancy that occurs when cleavage of the embryo occurs > 13 days after fertilization. Although vascular anastomoses between conjoined twins can lead to shunting of blood from one twin to the other, this would be unlikely to result in a difference in hematocrit because of shared blood supply. Moreover, conjoined twin pregnancies are associated with polyhydramnios, not oligohydramnios.
questions.hint: Delivery of twins with a significant disparity in birth weight and hematocrit, along with evidence of oligohydramnios (e.g., clubfoot, flattened nose) in the smaller newborn, should raise concern for twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome.

questions.text: A 36-year-old primigravid woman comes to the physician for a prenatal visit. She has no history of serious illness, and her only medication is a prenatal vitamin. The patient is a refugee who has recently immigrated to the United States and she has not had any routine prenatal care until now. Her last menstrual period was about 7 and a half months ago. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 85/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 125/70 mm Hg. Pelvic examination shows a fundal height of 32 cm. Cervical examination shows a closed cervix. Ultrasonography shows two female fetuses, each consistent in size with a 27-week gestation. One gestational sac and one placenta are visible. Fetal heart rates are within normal limits. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Admit the patient to the hospital for monitoring and schedule cesarean delivery at 32 weeks' gestation
Schedule a follow-up visit in 1 week and plan for labor induction at 38 weeks' gestation
Offer ablation of intertwin vascular anastomoses and screen the mother for sexually transmitted infections
Provide reassurance and continue with routine prenatal care only
Admit the patient to the hospital and perform immediate amnioreduction

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Women with monochorionic-monoamniotic twin pregnancies are at high risk of maternal and fetal complications, including premature labor and/or umbilical cord entanglement during labor. Because inpatient management improves the survival rates, women with monochorionic-monoamniotic twin pregnancies are often admitted at the beginning of the third trimester to allow for frequent fetal heart rate monitoring. Monochorionic-monoamniotic twins should be delivered via cesarean section to avoid fetal complications such as cord prolapse or entanglement. Elective preterm birth between 32–34 weeks' gestation and careful subsequent monitoring reduces adverse perinatal outcomes.
Image Description:

Ultrasound pelvis (15 weeks' gestation)

Twin pregnancy shows a single placenta. There is no intertwin membrane. The left twin is imaged in the coronal plane. The right twin is imaged in the sagittal plane.

A: amniotic fluid; H: head; P: placenta

B) INCORRECT:

Outpatient monitoring is recommended for pregnant patients with no active complaints or history of serious illness. Induction of labor at 38 weeks' gestation is the preferred management for uncomplicated dichorionic-diamniotic twin pregnancy. However, this woman is pregnant with monochorionic-monoamniotic twins, which carries a high risk for perinatal complications such as cord entanglement. Therefore, a different step in management is required.

C) INCORRECT:

Screening all pregnant women between 28–36 weeks' gestation for sexually transmitted infections is recommended as a part of routine prenatal care. Ablation of intertwin anastomoses is indicated in the case of twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome, a complication of monochorionic twin pregnancies. This woman's ultrasound, however, shows no evidence of twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome (e.g., selective fetal growth restriction).

D) INCORRECT:

Providing reassurance is appropriate if the results of the examination of the fetus and mother are normal. Routine prenatal care until delivery is indicated for women with uncomplicated pregnancies. This woman is pregnant with monochorionic-monoamniotic twins, which carries a high risk for perinatal complications. A different step in management is necessary.

E) INCORRECT:

Women with monochorionic-monoamniotic twin pregnancies are preferably admitted to the hospital at the beginning of the third trimester for close monitoring of fetal heart rates. However, amnioreduction is only indicated in patients with severe symptoms due to polyhydramnios (e.g., severe shortness of breath) or to improve uteroplacental perfusion in cases of twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome. This woman's ultrasound shows no evidence of polyhydramnios or twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome. Amnioreduction is not necessary at this point.
questions.hint: Ultrasonography shows a monochorionic-monoamniotic twin pregnancy, which is considered a high-risk pregnancy.

questions.text: A 25-year-old primigravid woman comes to the physician for her first prenatal visit 6 weeks after a positive home pregnancy test. During this period she has experienced mild nausea, but otherwise feels well and has had an uncomplicated pregnancy. She has no history of serious illness. Her only medications are prenatal supplements. Vital signs are within normal limits. Pelvic examination shows a fundal height of 16 cm. Fetal ultrasonography shows two fetuses that are both consistent in size with a 15-week gestation. There is a single placental mass; no intertwin membrane is visible. Fetal heart rates are within normal limits. The abdominal ultrasound is shown. Based on these findings, which of the following complications is most likely to occur during the patient's current pregnancy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Amniotic band sequence (ABS) can occur in any pregnancy due to an early rupture of the amniotic sac, but this is a very rare complication for which MCMA twin pregnancy is not a specific risk factor. Diamniotic pregnancies slightly increase the risk for ABS, as the greater amniotic surface area increases the likelihood of band formation. In diamniotic pregnancies, an intertwin membrane would be seen on ultrasonography (as a T sign or a lambda sign).
Image Description:

Ultrasound pelvis (gravid uterus)

Adjacent twins are separated by a thin membrane, which terminates at the placenta in a T configuration (T sign). This T sign is an indicator of a monochorionic diamniotic twin pregnancy.

A monochorionic diamniotic gestation may alternatively create a black triangular space (known as black lambda sign) at the uterine wall. This should not be confused with the triangular projection of chorion, which creates the lambda sign of a dichorionic pregnancy.

B) INCORRECT:

Intertwin amniotic fluid discordance can occur in diamniotic pregnancies, in which two amniotic sacs are present and an intertwin membrane would be seen on ultrasonography (as a T sign or a lambda sign). This patient has an MCMA twin pregnancy, in which the fetuses share a single amniotic sac. Amniotic fluid discordance is, therefore, not possible.
Image Description:

Transabdominal ultrasound of a pregnant patient

A dichorionic diamniotic twin pregnancy in the first trimester is seen. The triangular appearance of the chorion insinuating between layers of the intertwin membrane resembles the Greek letter lambda (λ; blue overlay). The lambda sign (also known as the “twin peak sign”) strongly suggests a dichorionic twin pregnancy.

Green overlay: placenta; red overlay: uterus; yellow overlay: fetus

C) INCORRECT:

Spontaneous fetomaternal hemorrhage (FMH) is a rare complication that can occur in any pregnancy, regardless of the number of fetuses. Risk factors for spontaneous FMH include placental abnormalities, maternal trauma, and invasive procedures. MCMA twin pregnancy is not a risk factor for this condition.

D) CORRECT:

MCMA gestations are associated with the complications of a shared amniotic cavity (e.g., umbilical cord entanglement) as well as the complications of a shared placental vasculature (e.g., twin-twin transfusion syndrome). Umbilical cord entanglement occurs in almost all monoamniotic twin pregnancies due to the close insertion of the umbilical cords on the chorionic surface. Knotting of the cord is often present in the first trimester. Free movement of both twins may cause tightening at any time during the pregnancy, resulting in cord compression and occlusion of the umbilical blood vessels. Intermittent disruption of blood flow may impair fetal growth and increase the risk of neurologic morbidity. A prolonged occlusion may result in fetal demise. MCMA gestation is the least common form of twin pregnancy but has the highest risk of complications. Close fetal surveillance after 24 weeks' gestation and antenatal corticosteroid administration followed by elective cesarean delivery at 32–34 weeks' gestation are recommended to improve outcomes in MCMA pregnancies.

E) INCORRECT:

Risk factors for precipitous labor include placental abruption, multiparity, and intrauterine growth restriction in singleton pregnancies. Multiple gestations are not associated with precipitous labor.
questions.hint: The ultrasound image shows a monochorionic monoamniotic (MCMA) twin pregnancy, in which the fetuses share a single placenta and a single amniotic sac

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman gravida 2, para 1, at 10 weeks’ gestation comes to the office for a routine prenatal visit. Over the past 2 weeks, she has noticed mild swelling around her ankles. Her previous pregnancy was complicated by a first-degree cervical laceration. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 136/82 mm Hg. Pelvic examination shows the fundal height between the umbilicus and the xiphoid. Cervical examination shows a closed cervix. Ultrasonography shows two gestational sacs and two placentas separated by a thick membrane. Two fetal heart tones are heard on Doppler. The patient is at greatest risk for which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Uterine inversion can result from uterine atony, which is more common in multiple pregnancy compared to singleton pregnancy because of uterine overdistention. However, there are more common complications than uterine atony and inversion in women with multiple pregnancy.

B) CORRECT:

Spontaneous preterm labor (i.e., < 37 weeks of gestation) is the most common complication of multiple pregnancies and is associated with increased maternal and neonatal morbidity and mortality. In comparison to women with singleton pregnancy, women with multiple pregnancy are at greater risk for most pregnancy complications (except for postterm pregnancy and macrosomia). The increased risk of preterm labor may be attributed to uterine overdistention, which induces the upregulation of oxytocin receptors, formation of myometrial gap junctions, and production of local inflammatory cytokines and prostaglandins, all of which prepare the uterus for labor.

C) INCORRECT:

Multiple pregnancy does not increase the risk for hypotension; it is associated with hypertensive pregnancy complications (e.g., preeclampsia, HELLP syndrome).

D) INCORRECT:

Twin-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS) is a complication that occurs in 10–15% of monochorionic twin pregnancies. This patient's ultrasonographic findings show two separate placentas (i.e., a dichorionic twin pregnancy), which makes TTTS an unlikely complication.

E) INCORRECT:

Umbilical cord entanglement is a complication of monoamniotic multiple pregnancies. This patient's ultrasonographic findings show two separate gestational sacs (i.e., a diamniotic twin pregnancy), which makes umbilical cord entanglement an unlikely complication.
questions.hint: This woman is pregnant with dichorionic-diamniotic twins, as indicated by the examination and ultrasonography findings. She is at greatest risk for a complication that may also be seen in pregnant women with a history of cervical insufficiency.

questions.text: A 36-year-old primigravid woman presents for a prenatal visit. She has no history of serious illness, and her only medication is a prenatal vitamin. The patient is a refugee who has recently immigrated to the United States and she has not had any routine prenatal care until now. Her last menstrual period was about 7 and a half months ago. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 85/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 125/70 mm Hg. Pelvic examination shows a fundal height of 32 cm. Cervical examination shows a closed cervix. Ultrasonography shows two female fetuses, each consistent in size with a 27-week gestation. One gestational sac and one placenta are visible. Fetal heart rates are within normal limits. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

Schedule a follow-up visit in 1 week and plan for labor induction at 38 weeks' gestation
Offer ablation of intertwin vascular anastomoses and screen the mother for sexually transmitted infections
Provide reassurance and continue with routine prenatal care only
Admit the patient to the hospital and perform immediate amnioreduction

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Women with monochorionic-monoamniotic twin pregnancies are at high risk of maternal and fetal complications, including premature labor and/or umbilical cord entanglement during labor. Because inpatient management improves the survival rates, women with monochorionic-monoamniotic twin pregnancies are often admitted at the beginning of the third trimester to allow for frequent fetal heart rate monitoring. Monochorionic-monoamniotic twins should be delivered via cesarean section to avoid fetal complications such as cord prolapse or entanglement. Elective preterm birth between 32–34 weeks' gestation and careful subsequent monitoring reduces adverse perinatal outcomes.
Image Description:

Ultrasound pelvis (15 weeks' gestation)

Twin pregnancy shows a single placenta. There is no intertwin membrane. The left twin is imaged in the coronal plane. The right twin is imaged in the sagittal plane.

A: amniotic fluid; H: head; P: placenta

B) INCORRECT:

Outpatient monitoring is recommended for pregnant patients with no active complaints or history of serious illness. Induction of labor at 38 weeks' gestation is the preferred management for uncomplicated dichorionic-diamniotic twin pregnancy. However, this woman is pregnant with monochorionic-monoamniotic twins, which carries a high risk for perinatal complications such as cord entanglement. Therefore, a different step in management is required.

C) INCORRECT:

Screening all pregnant women between 28–36 weeks' gestation for sexually transmitted infections is recommended as a part of routine prenatal care. Ablation of intertwin anastomoses is indicated in the case of twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome, a complication of monochorionic twin pregnancies. This woman's ultrasound, however, shows no evidence of twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome (e.g., selective fetal growth restriction).

D) INCORRECT:

Providing reassurance is appropriate if the results of the examination of the fetus and mother are normal. Routine prenatal care until delivery is indicated for women with uncomplicated pregnancies. This woman is pregnant with monochorionic-monoamniotic twins, which carries a high risk for perinatal complications. A different step in management is necessary.

E) INCORRECT:

Women with monochorionic-monoamniotic twin pregnancies are preferably admitted to the hospital at the beginning of the third trimester for close monitoring of fetal heart rates. However, amnioreduction is only indicated in patients with severe symptoms due to polyhydramnios (e.g., severe shortness of breath) or to improve uteroplacental perfusion in cases of twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome. This woman's ultrasound shows no evidence of polyhydramnios or twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome. Amnioreduction is not necessary at this point.
questions.hint: Ultrasonography shows a monochorionic-monoamniotic twin pregnancy, which is considered a high-risk pregnancy.

questions.text:
An 18-year-old G1P0 woman presents to the clinic with a new pregnancy at 12 weeks by her last menstrual period. An ultrasound confirms a twin gestation with two distinct gestational sacs, each with its own thick chorion and separate amniotic membranes. Two separate placental masses with no apparent vascular anastomoses are visualized. She has no significant medical history and denies any family history of multiple births. She is concerned about the possibility of twin-twin transfusion syndrome and wonders if the twins share the same genetic composition (see report).
Ultrasound: Twin gestation with two distinct gestational sacs, each with its own thick chorion and separate amniotic membranes. Two separate placental masses with no apparent vascular anastomoses.
Which of the following statements best describes the most likely type of twin pregnancy in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Dichorionic diamniotic placentation is common in dizygotic twins, with separate chorions, amniotic sacs, and placentas. While monozygotic twins can occasionally exhibit this configuration if the zygote splits very early, it is uncommon. The ultrasound findings of two separate placental masses and no vascular anastomoses strongly suggest a dizygotic twin pregnancy, making genetic identity unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

Monozygotic monochorionic diamniotic twins result from a single zygote splitting between days 4 and 8, leading to shared chorion but separate amniotic sacs. Typically, there is one placental mass with a thin dividing membrane and possible vascular anastomoses. The ultrasound shows two distinct gestational sacs, each with its own thick chorion and separate placental masses, which is inconsistent with this configuration.

C) INCORRECT:

Monozygotic monochorionic monoamniotic twins arise from a single fertilized egg that splits later in development, resulting in shared chorion and amnion, and a single placenta with potential vascular anastomoses. The ultrasound findings of two distinct gestational sacs, each with its own thick chorion and separate amniotic membranes, and two separate placental masses, do not support this configuration.

D) CORRECT:

Dizygotic twins result from the fertilization of two separate ova, leading to independent embryonic development. Each embryo forms its own trophoblast, resulting in a dichorionic diamniotic configuration with two distinct gestational sacs, each with its own thick chorion and amniotic membrane. The presence of two separate placental masses without vascular anastomoses aligns with this type of twin gestation. Twin-twin transfusion syndrome is not a concern in dizygotic twins, as it occurs in monochorionic twins sharing a single placenta.

Key learning point: Dizygotic twins are always dichorionic and diamniotic, as they result from the fertilization of two separate eggs, each developing its own placenta and amniotic sac.

questions.text: A 29-year-old at 28 weeks with a dichorionic twin pregnancy asks about potential serious complications. Which factor most commonly causes morbidity in multiple gestations?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Placental abruption involves premature separation of the placenta and can cause significant morbidity. However, in multiple gestations, especially dichorionic twins, the primary morbidity arises from preterm labor due to uterine overdistension, rather than placental abruption.

B) INCORRECT:

Hypertensive disorders, including gestational hypertension and preeclampsia, are complications in twin pregnancies due to increased placental mass and vascular demands. However, the primary morbidity in multiple gestations is due to preterm birth, which poses a higher risk of neonatal complications.

C) CORRECT:

Preterm birth is the most common cause of morbidity in multiple gestations, including dichorionic twin pregnancies. Increased uterine distension in these pregnancies often leads to preterm labor, resulting in neonatal complications such as respiratory distress syndrome, intraventricular hemorrhage, and long-term neurodevelopmental issues. Despite a lower risk of complications related to placental sharing in dichorionic twins, the risk of preterm birth remains significant. Early identification and management of preterm labor signs are crucial to improving neonatal outcomes.

Key learning point: Prematurity is the most common cause of morbidity in multiple gestation pregnancies due to the increased risk of preterm birth.

D) INCORRECT:

Twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS) occurs in monochorionic pregnancies due to shared placental circulation. In dichorionic twin pregnancies, each fetus has its own placenta, eliminating the risk of TTTS. Therefore, TTTS is not a concern in dichorionic gestations.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old G2P1 woman at approximately 7 weeks gestation by last menstrual period presents to the clinic with lower abdominal cramping and light vaginal spotting for one day. She reports no passage of clots or tissue. She denies heavy bleeding. Physical examination reveals mild suprapubic tenderness. Vital signs are stable. She has not had any imaging studies during this pregnancy. Laboratory results are pending.
What is the most appropriate next step in evaluation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Dilation and curettage is reserved for confirmed retained products, heavy bleeding, or incomplete abortion. In stable early pregnancy with light spotting, the priority is to assess pregnancy viability and location using noninvasive methods. D&C poses risks like uterine perforation and infection.

B) INCORRECT:

Serum progesterone measurement can indicate pregnancy viability, but it is adjunctive to imaging. Low levels may suggest nonviability, but ultrasound is preferred for direct visualization of the gestational sac and fetal activity. Progesterone levels alone can be indeterminate due to physiological variations.

C) INCORRECT:

Intramuscular methotrexate treats confirmed ectopic pregnancies, requiring prior imaging and laboratory confirmation. Without ultrasound confirmation of an ectopic pregnancy, methotrexate risks disrupting a viable intrauterine pregnancy. It is inappropriate for stable patients with symptoms possibly indicating a threatened abortion.

D) CORRECT:

Transvaginal ultrasound is crucial in early pregnancy evaluation, especially with symptoms like vaginal spotting and cramping. It provides high-resolution images of the gestational sac, yolk sac, and embryo, confirming intrauterine pregnancy and assessing fetal cardiac activity. At 7 weeks' gestation, detecting a gestational sac with cardiac activity is reassuring. This imaging can also identify subchorionic hemorrhages or uterine abnormalities, influencing prognosis and guiding management.

Key learning point: In early pregnancy with abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding, a transvaginal ultrasound is the most appropriate next step to assess pregnancy location and viability.

questions.text:
A 29-year-old primigravida at 38 weeks with a dichorionic diamniotic twin pregnancy presents for routine evaluation. She reports regular fetal movements and no contractions. Ultrasound confirms both fetuses in vertex presentation and estimates fetal weights of 2.8 kg and 2.7 kg. Amniotic fluid indices are normal, and no gross fetal anomalies are noted.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: External cephalic version for fetal repositioning
Trial of labor with close intrapartum monitoring

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Immediate cesarean section is typically reserved for nonreassuring fetal status, abnormal presentations, or maternal complications like severe preeclampsia. In this scenario, both fetuses are vertex, fetal movements are reassuring, and ultrasound findings are normal, indicating no urgent need for cesarean delivery.

B) INCORRECT:

Delaying delivery until 40 weeks is not recommended for twin pregnancies due to increased risks of uteroplacental insufficiency and stillbirth. In dichorionic diamniotic twins, delivery is typically planned by 38 weeks to mitigate these risks.

C) INCORRECT:

External cephalic version is used to reposition a breech or transverse fetus to vertex, mainly in singleton pregnancies. In this case, both fetuses are already in vertex presentation, making ECV unnecessary and inappropriate.

D) CORRECT:

In a dichorionic diamniotic twin pregnancy at 38 weeks with both fetuses in vertex presentation, a trial of labor is appropriate. Vaginal delivery is generally safe when the first twin is vertex. Close intrapartum monitoring is essential to manage potential complications, especially for the second twin after the first is delivered. Continuous fetal heart rate monitoring is crucial. Delivering twins by 38 weeks reduces risks associated with prolonged gestation, such as stillbirth, making this timing suitable for labor.

Key learning point: In twin pregnancies where both twins are in vertex presentation and there are no complications, spontaneous vaginal delivery is the appropriate management.

questions.text:
A 26-year-old G1P0 woman at 30 weeks of gestation is in the Outpatient Clinic. She is carrying a monochorionic monoamniotic twin pregnancy with the first twin in breech presentation. She has had normal fetal growth, no contractions, and stable vitals. A recent ultrasound at 29 weeks showed normal amniotic fluid volume but close proximity of the umbilical cords. She has no other complications (see report).
Ultrasound: Normal amniotic fluid volume; close proximity of the umbilical cords
Which of the following is the most appropriate management?

choices.text: Attempt external cephalic version at 34 weeks
Plan to deliver vaginally at 37 weeks
Perform an immediate cesarean at 30 weeks
Schedule a cesarean delivery at 32-34 weeks

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

External cephalic version (ECV) is typically used for singleton breech presentations with adequate amniotic fluid. In monochorionic monoamniotic twins, shared amniotic sac increases cord entanglement risk. Attempting ECV could disrupt cord configuration and compromise fetal safety. Limited space in twin pregnancies further reduces ECV feasibility.

B) INCORRECT:

Monochorionic monoamniotic twins have a high risk of cord entanglement due to a shared amniotic sac. The breech presentation of the first twin complicates vaginal delivery. Early cesarean delivery is preferred to reduce risks of cord compression and fetal compromise, making vaginal delivery at 37 weeks inappropriate.

C) INCORRECT:

Immediate cesarean at 30 weeks may seem reasonable due to cord entanglement risk in monochorionic monoamniotic twins. However, the patient is asymptomatic with stable vitals and normal fetal growth. Immediate delivery risks prematurity complications, such as respiratory distress syndrome, outweighing potential benefits without signs of fetal distress.

D) CORRECT:

Monochorionic monoamniotic twin pregnancies lack an intervening membrane, increasing the risk of umbilical cord entanglement and fetal compromise. The breech presentation of the first twin further contraindicates a trial of vaginal delivery. Scheduling a cesarean delivery between 32 and 34 weeks balances achieving fetal lung maturity with reducing risks of cord compression. This approach minimizes perinatal morbidity and mortality in high-risk twin pregnancies.

Key learning point: In cases of monochorionic monoamniotic twins, cesarean section is recommended due to the high risk of complications such as cord entanglement, especially when the first twin is in breech presentation.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a 3-week history of nausea and fatigue. Her menstrual cycles are irregular, occurring every 24 to 33 days and lasting 4–6 days. Her last menstrual period was 7 weeks ago. Her temperature is 37°C, pulse is 95/min, and blood pressure is 100/70 mm Hg. On pelvic examination, her uterus is enlarged. Her serum β-hCG concentration is 96,000 IU/L (<5). An abdominal ultrasound is provided. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A hydatidiform mole may be suspected in a case of prolonged amenorrhea associated with elevated beta-hCG levels. However, ultrasonography in a molar pregnancy would not reveal any fetal parts or amniotic fluid, but rather an echogenic mass interspersed with many hypoechogenic cystic spaces (“Swiss cheese,” “bunch of grapes,” or “snowstorm” appearance). Moreover, the elevation in serum beta-hCG levels is usually markedly higher (> 100,000 IU/L) than expected for the gestational age in molar pregnancies.

B) INCORRECT:

This patient presents with an elevated serum beta-hCG and 7 weeks of amenorrhea, indicating a live pregnancy. Her ultrasonography clearly shows two embryos, which indicates a twin pregnancy. However, a monochorionic-diamniotic twin pregnancy is characterized on ultrasonography by the "T" sign; a thin membrane resembling the letter "T" separates the amniotic sacs within a common chorionic sac. This typical feature is absent in this patient's ultrasonography.

C) CORRECT:

This patient presents elevated serum beta-hCG and 7 weeks of amenorrhea, indicating a live pregnancy. Her ultrasonography clearly shows two embryos, each with an individual gestational and amniotic sac. Also, a typical lambda sign is seen where the chorion joins the placenta. These findings are characteristic of a dichorionic-diamniotic twin pregnancy.

Key learning point: Dichorionic-diamniotic twin pregnancies are identified on ultrasound by two embryos, each with its own gestational and amniotic sac, and the presence of the lambda (twin peak) sign.
Image Description:

Ultrasound pelvis (gravid uterus)

A thick inter-twin membrane containing both amnion and chorion separates adjacent twin embryos, with a triangular projection of chorion visible at the base of the membrane. The appearance produced by this projection of tissue has been termed the lambda sign (also the twin peak sign) because of its resemblance to the Greek symbol λ (blue overlay).

Although its absence is not sufficient to exclude dichorionicity, the lambda sign is a strong indicator of a dichorionic diamniotic pregnancy. In a monochorionic diamniotic pregancy, the inter-twin membrane may either terminate in a T configuration (T sign) or create a black triangular space with the uterine wall, sometimes termed the black lambda sign.

E: embryo; yellow overlay: uterine wall

D) INCORRECT:

Although a bicornuate uterus pregnancy could manifest as two separate cavities on ultrasound, a single embryo usually appears in only one horn of the malformed uterus while the other horn is empty. In contrast, this patient presents with two, clearly visible embryos on ultrasonography. Also, a bicornuate uterus is associated with other features, such as a past history of dyspareunia, menorrhagia, etc., which this patient lacks.

E) INCORRECT:

Prolonged amenorrhea, elevated β-hCG levels, and the appearance of embryonal parts on ultrasonography may indicate a partial hydatidiform mole. However, a partial hydatidiform mole is also associated with an enlarged placenta and cystic spaces within the placenta, both of which are absent here.

questions.text: You are caring for a 24-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, who delivers two male newborns at 36 weeks' gestation. She did not receive prenatal care. The first newborn weighs 2250 g and the second weighs 2900 g. Examination of the smaller newborn reveals low-set ears, retrognathia, and right-sided clubfoot. The hematocrit is 0.41 L/L for the smaller newborn and 0.69 L/L for the larger newborn. Which one of the following best describes this pregnancy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Approximately 20–30% of monozygotic twin pregnancies are dichorionic-diamniotic. Since each fetus has its own placenta and circulation, it is not possible for vascular anastomoses to develop that could lead to twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome.

B) CORRECT:

Approximately 70% of monozygotic twin pregnancies are monochorionic-diamniotic. Sharing a common placenta can lead to twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome, a complication caused by unbalanced vascular anastomoses in which blood flows in a fixed direction from one twin to the other. Since the fetuses have separate amniotic sacs, this causes oligohydramnios in the donor twin's amniotic sac and polyhydramnios in the recipient twin's amniotic sac. The donor twin develops anemia, oliguria, and complications of oligohydramnios (e.g., craniofacial abnormalities and clubfoot due to intrauterine growth restriction). The recipient twin develops polycythemia.

Key learning point: Monochorionic-diamniotic monozygotic twins share a placenta, predisposing them to twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome with anemia and growth restriction in the donor twin and polycythemia in the recipient.

C) INCORRECT:

Dichorionic-monoamniotic monozygotic twin pregnancies are not possible. The amnion develops within the chorion. If the chorion has cleaved (dichorionic), then each will form its own amnion (diamniotic). It is not possible to have one amnion within two chorions.

D) INCORRECT:

Monozygotic twin pregnancies are rarely monochorionic-monoamniotic. Twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome can develop in these pregnancies because of the shared placenta and cause a discrepancy in hematocrit. However, because the fetuses share one amniotic sac, complications of oligohydramnios affecting only one of the twins would not be expected. Monochorionic-monoamniotic twin pregnancies can be complicated by umbilical cord entanglement rather than amniotic fluid discordance.

E) INCORRECT:

All dizygotic twin pregnancies are dichorionic-diamniotic. Since each fetus has its own placenta and circulation, it is not possible for vascular anastomoses to develop that could lead to twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome.
questions.hint: Delivery of twins with a significant disparity in birth weight and hematocrit, along with complications of oligohydramnios (e.g., clubfoot, low-set ears, retrognathia) in the smaller newborn, should raise concern for twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome.

questions.text: You are seeing a 29-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 10 weeks’ gestation, who presents to your clinic for a routine prenatal visit. Over the past 2 weeks, she has noticed mild swelling around her ankles. Her previous pregnancy was complicated by a first-degree cervical laceration. Her temperature is 37.0°C, pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 136/82 mm Hg. On pelvic examination, the fundal height is between the umbilicus and the xiphoid. Cervical examination shows a closed cervix. Ultrasonography reveals two gestational sacs and two placentas separated by a thick membrane. Two fetal heart tones are detected on Doppler. This patient is at greatest risk for which one of the following complications?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Umbilical cord entanglement is a complication of monoamniotic multiple pregnancies. This patient's ultrasonographic findings show two separate gestational sacs (i.e., a diamniotic twin pregnancy), which makes umbilical cord entanglement an unlikely complication.

B) INCORRECT:

Uterine inversion can result from uterine atony, which is more common in multiple pregnancy compared to singleton pregnancy because of uterine overdistention. However, there are more common complications than uterine atony and inversion in women with multiple pregnancy.

C) INCORRECT:

Twin-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS) is a complication that occurs in 10–15% of monochorionic twin pregnancies. This patient's ultrasonographic findings show two separate placentas (i.e., a dichorionic twin pregnancy), which makes TTTS an unlikely complication.

D) CORRECT:

Spontaneous preterm labor (i.e., < 37 weeks of gestation) is the most common complication of multiple pregnancies and is associated with increased maternal and neonatal morbidity and mortality. In comparison to women with singleton pregnancy, women with multiple pregnancy are at greater risk for most pregnancy complications (except for postterm pregnancy and macrosomia). The increased risk of preterm labor may be attributed to uterine overdistention, which induces the upregulation of oxytocin receptors, formation of myometrial gap junctions, and production of local inflammatory cytokines and prostaglandins, all of which prepare the uterus for labor.

Key learning point: The most common complication of dichorionic-diamniotic twin pregnancy is preterm labor due to uterine overdistention and increased uterine activity.

E) INCORRECT:

Multiple pregnancy does not increase the risk for hypotension; it is associated with hypertensive pregnancy complications (e.g., preeclampsia, HELLP syndrome).
questions.hint: This woman is pregnant with dichorionic-diamniotic twins, as indicated by the examination and ultrasonography findings. She is at greatest risk for a complication that may also be seen in pregnant women with a history of cervical insufficiency.

questions.text: A 29-year-old at 10 weeks has ultrasound showing twin fetuses, each with a separate placenta and amniotic sac. Which embryologic event most likely accounts for these findings?

choices.text: Cleavage between days 4 and 7 after fertilization
Cleavage after day 13 of embryonic development
Cleavage between days 8 and 12 after fertilization

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cleavage between days 4 and 7 typically results in monochorionic diamniotic twins, where twins share a placenta but have separate amniotic sacs. This occurs because the division happens at the blastocyst stage, after the chorion has formed. The ultrasound findings of separate placentas and amniotic sacs indicate an earlier cleavage.

B) CORRECT:

Cleavage within the first 3 days after fertilization results in dichorionic diamniotic twins, where each fetus has its own placenta and amniotic sac. This occurs because the inner cell mass divides early, leading to two distinct blastocysts, each developing its own trophoblast and inner cell mass. This early division distinguishes these twins from those with shared placental or amniotic structures, which occur with later cleavage.

Key learning point: Dichorionic Diamniotic twins result from cleavage of the fertilized egg within 0-72 hours after ovulation, leading to each twin having its own chorion and amniotic sac.

C) INCORRECT:

Cleavage after day 13 can result in conjoined twins due to incomplete separation, as the embryonic disc is already well-differentiated. Twins sharing components of their amniotic environment are typical in this scenario. The ultrasound findings of separate placentas and amniotic sacs indicate an earlier cleavage.

D) INCORRECT:

Cleavage between days 8 and 12 usually results in monochorionic monoamniotic twins, where twins share both a chorion and an amniotic sac. This occurs because the division happens after both the chorionic and amniotic membranes have formed. The ultrasound findings of separate placentas and amniotic sacs indicate an earlier cleavage.
